discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Snowflake will only check the schema the UDF belongs to

The correct answer is B.

In queries, unqualified object names are resolved through a search path.
The SEARCH_PATH is not used inside views or Writing User-Defined Functions (UDFs). All unqualified objects in a view or UDF definition will be resolved in the view’s or UDF’s schema only.
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/name-resolution#name-resolution-in-queries

Selected Answer: B
correct

Selected Answer A
if search_path than it has to be A

comments.content: Not for UDF or views. so answer is B

questions.question_text:
A Snowflake user is writing a User-Defined Function (UDF) with some unqualified object names.

How will those object names be resolved during execution?

choices.D: Snowflake will first check the current schema, and then the PUBLIC schema of the current database.
choices.C: Snowflake will first check the current schema, and then the schema the previous query used.
choices.B: Snowflake will only check the schema the UDF belongs to.
choices.A: Snowflake will resolve them according to the SEARCH_PATH parameter.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Economy

Conserves credits by favoring keeping running clusters fully-loaded rather than starting additional clusters, which may result in queries being queued and taking longer to complete.
D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
D. To conserve credits by keeping running clusters fully loaded

for sure D

choices.B: To increase performance of the clusters
